title: Large-Scale Object Classification using Label Relation Graphs

author: Jia Deng, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Michigan State University

segmentation: Object classification is one of the fundamental building blocks in visual recognition is the task of assigning semantic labels to objects.
Typically we have multiple labels and would like to find out whether each of them applies.
Particular would like to predict probability for each label.
A commonly used pipeline is to 1st extract features and then apply a classifier that helps label probabilities.
For the choice of classifier, there are typically 2 standard variance.

One is the logistic regression, in which case we have a set of independent binary classifiers, one for each label, to generate the probabilities we obtain the real value of score for each label and then pass it through a sigmoid function.
Here assumption is that there are no constraints between labels and the probabilities are free to take values independently.
Another standard choice is a softmax classifier.
The computation is the same as solid logistics regression, except that we have an additional normalization step in which where we normalize the probabilities to make sure that they sum up to one.
In this case, we assume that the labels are mutually exclusive and a big probability for one label would have to suppress probabilities of others.
In the real world, however, labels have much richer relations.
Some labels are mutually exclusive.
For example, an object cannot be both dark and cut.
Some labels are hierarchical, for example.
A corgi is a type of dog.
Some labels can overlap, which means that they have no constraints between them.
For example, a corgi may or may not be a puppy and vice versa.
We can see that either softmax or logistic regression makes simplistic assumptions.
Softmax on one hand assume mutually exclusive labels with logistic regression.
On the other hand, assumes independent labels and these last two relaxed.
So the question is whether we can have something more flexible.
So of this talk is therefore to propose a new classification model that respects real world Labor Relations and makes consistent predictions.
This is an initial step toward a bigger goal of connecting visual perception and common sense knowledge.
Concretely, would like to perform joint inference using a visual model and the Knowledge Graph.
In this work, we assume that the Knowledge Graph is given and fixed or goes to make use of this prior knowledge so that our visual model makes better predictions.
For the rest of the talk, I will first introduce our formalism, called Hex graph, to encode prior knowledge.
Next, I'll talk about our classification model and how to do exact inference followed by experiments and conclusion.
They start with encoding a prior knowledge.
We should use the formalism called hierarchy and exclusion graph or simply hex graph.
Each node here represents the label, and each edge includes relation.
There are two types of edges that direct ones and the undirected ones.
The director ones represent hierarchical relations where we join Arrow from the parent to a child.
The undirected edges represent exclusive relations.
If there are no edges between two nodes, it means that there are no constraints directly placed on them, and they are free to take values independently.
Let's look at some examples.
The labels can be mutually exclusive, in which case the hash graph would be fully connected with exclusion edges.
The labels can also be independent.
In which case the hex graph would have no edges at all.
A hex graph for the real world is likely a combination of many different scenarios.
It's worth pointing out some complexity of real world hex graphs.
One is that the hierarchy is typically a DAG instead of a tree.
For example, the boy note is a subset of both male and child.
Also.
The siblings in the hierarchy are not necessarily mutually exclusive.
For example, male and female exclusive whereas male and child or not?
The hex graph allows us to define what label configurations are consistent with prior knowledge.
In particular, we can now introduce important notion called the state space, without any loss of generality.
Let's assume all labels are binary.
That is, for any labels there are two to the end label configurations.
Given a hex graph, each edge defines the constraints on the values.
Two labels can take.
In particular, the hierarchical edge means that it's illegal for the child to take one if the parent is 0, for example, it's impossible for an object to be a corgi, but not a dog.
An exclusive edge, on the other hand, means that it's illegal for both labels to be one that is impossible to be.
Both dog and cat.
If a label configuration violates any constraint defined by the high scraf, the label configuration is considered illegal.
The state space of Hashgraph is then the set of all legal configurations.
In general, the more densely connected the hex graph, the smaller save space.
This is the observation that will be.
Review to be useful in our later discussion.
Now, having introduced the HECTOGRAPH formalism, we're ready to describe our classification model.
A classification model is a conditional random field where we have one input score per label and we model the joint distribution of label assignments given in the input scores.
Each label has a binary, has a unary potential that depends only on its own input score.
Specifically, the unary potential is a sigmoid of its input score.
If the label takes value one.
And it takes value 1 minus sigmoid otherwise.
As you can see, this is exactly the same as the formulation of logistic regression.
There is a pairwise potential for each label pairs.
Depends and it depends only on the label assignment.
The pairwise potential is 0 if the label assignment violates any constraint defined by the hex graph.
Otherwise the potential is 1.
In other words, the pairwise potential sets the probability of any illegal configuration to 0.
Another, but it has no effect otherwise.
Stupid, obtain a proper probability distribution.
We also need to compute the partition function.
That is, we need to sum the potentials of all configurations.
Note that since illegal configurations have zero potential, it is the same as just summing over all legal ones.
In practice, we are often interested in the probability of a single label instead of a joint assignment.
To compute that, we need to perform another summation to marginalized the rest of labels.
A nice property of our late model is the standard model such as softmax, and largest regressions are special cases.
If we let all labels be mutually exclusive then it's easy to verify that we arrive at the softmax model, except that we have additional constant one in the denominator.
This additional constant corresponds to the class of novelty above.
That is, the configuration of our labels being 0.
On the other hand, if we let all labels be independent, then it's easy to verify, arrive at the largest regression.
A model that unifies these two standard models.
To perform training, we put our model as the final layer on top of deep neural network and perform full backpropagation.

Note that our model has no parameters to learn because the parameters for the input scores can be specified in the previous layers in the back propagation framework, or learning objective is to maximize the marginal probability of the observed labels.
For example, if a training images labeled as dog.
We treat all other labels as unknown and maximize the marginal probability of dog.
We have fully specified the model, but haven't addressed the computational issues.
Now let's switch gear to discuss efficient inference.
We need efficient inference to compute the partition function as well as performing marginalization.
But if we treat our model as a generic CRF, exactly influence intractable, this is becausw the CF has can be very densely connected and thus has a large tree width.
However, a key observation is that the dense connections in terms of exclusions are actually good.
In particular, if I have lots and lots of exclusions as a typical for object labels, then the state space can be small.
For example, if all labels are mutually exclusive, then the state space is linear in the number of labels instead of exponential.
A small state space means that we can do efficient inference.
This is because we can find the legal configurations into the events and only perform inference on the on them.
Please consult a paper for more details and rigorous analysis.
Another key observation is that for each hex graph there is a family of equivalent graphs that expressed the same constraints.

For example, if we know Cardigan, Welsh Corgi is a type of dog, it's type of corgi and cookies type of dog, then we can add an edge between Cardigan, Welsh Corgi and dog without changing the meaning of the graph.
In addition, if we know dog and Cat exclusive and Puppy is a type of dog, then we can add introduce that puppy is exclusive to cut.
And and and add an exclusive edge there.
We can Add all these implied edges to make the graph as dense as possible.
This will help us prune the legal states.
On the other hand, we can remove all the redundant edges to make the graph as sparse as possible.
This will hopefully give us a sparse graph with a small truth.
Which would be good for dynamic programming?
We can now present our inference algorithm, give a hex graph.
We first make it as sparse as possible and build a junction tree based on it.
We then make the graph as dense as possible and use this dense graph to prune the states.
For each click of the junction tree.
For example, the red edges are added from the dense graph to reduce the state space.
Finally, we perform message passing on the junction tree.
Note that all steps except message passing are performed offline.
That's our influence can be done with very little overhead.
Now let's move on to experiments.
Our first experiments is on learning with weak labels, real world image labels follow along tail distribution.
Whether many more basic level labels then fine green ones.
The basic level labels are weaker because they don't have information on the sub categories.
We know it's a dog, but we don't know which type of dog it is.
The hypothesis is that our classification model can improve recognition of angry labels by jointly training with basic category labels.
This is because in our model, the marginal probability of dog depends on the scores of sub dogs.
Thus the weights for sub categories can benefit when we try to fit the examples of dogs.
Here we use the Internet Challenge 2012 data and semantic hierarchy.
Things all images are labeled leaf nodes.
We relabel a weakened portion of leaf labels up the hierarchy to basic category labels.
Doing test will still evaluate on recognition of fine grained categories.
We compare our model with various baselines, including different strategies of using softmax and logistic regressions on the same training data.
We found that our model consistently outperformed these baselines.
Another experiment is on zero shot recognition.
Here we have the object attribute knowledge.
We use the animals with attribute data set introduced by Lampitt at all.
We first build a hex graph based on animal atricle relations.
For example, a polar bear is not black means an exclusive edge between polar bear and black.
A polar bear is white means that polar bear is child of white during training were given all animal attribute relations and deserve only animal labels.
But our model can directly learn the attributes based on the relations during test.
The model can predict new classes with no training images because it can reason using attributed animal attribute relations.
A model is thus easily adapted to do transfer learning and encouragingly.
It achieves comperable performance on this task.
Finally, I'd like to put our work in perspective.
This work draws inspiration from a lot of prior work on the interplay between visual models and external knowledge.
This includes multi label annotation transfer learning and extracting common sense knowledge.
I work a difference in several ways.
First, we jointly model hierarchy and description relations.
Secondly, our model is generalized classifier that also allows transfer learning.
3rd, our focus is not on extracting knowledge but on averaging a given knowledge base.
To conclude, we have proposed a unified framework for single object classification that generalizes standard classification models.
